reviewText:
It's been a while since I write a review... so here goes nothing.

The Wolf Among Us was amazing from start to finish, Telltale really shines in their newest game. It's based on the Fables comic book series. You play as Bigby Wolf, or The Big Bad Wolf, who is sheriff of Fabletown. It follows through a string of connected murdles that lead through an unpredictable story that's witty and deceptive. There's so much to love about this game, you can go into it knowing nothing of the comic series, as I did, and still get so much out of it. It's perfect as a prequel and it definitely sparked an interest to check out the comics.

The story is strung together throughout all 5 episodes, and Bigby really shows why he's called The Big Bad Wolf, he makes a perfect sheriff and can definitely back up his bark with his bite, which episode 5 showcased completely what he's capable of if pushed to his limits. I thought episode 5 brought the season to a perfect close, but also leaves the door open just enough for a second season.

The controls are easy, choosing what to say when prompted, exploring environments is fun and rewarding, and the script is perfect, especially Bigby's lines. It made me laugh, made me cry, made me sad, and I really felt like I connected with the characters and Fabletown. I really feel like this is Telltale's best work and that's saying something, considering how much I love The Walking Dead.

There's nothing I can really say is wrong with the game, the choices you make seamlessly weave the story along and I felt like my choices affected the story in a way that felt very personal. I definitely recommend it to anyone who likes comic books or fans of Telltale Games, or even if you liked The Walking Dead game....no not Survival Instinct. But definitely give it a try! You won't regret it. It has an amazing story, the graphics are beautiful and really looks like a comic book. The Wolf Among Us deserves so much more mainstream attention than it has received.

TL;DR  One of the best story based games I have ever played hands down. They need to make a sequel to this game. Like seriously.

reviewText: Anyone else getting this awkward feeling Telltale Games has a really objectionable stance towards tangible gameplay? They continue with their steady decline away from it in the effort to focus on storytelling instead, as if the two are mutually exclusive somehow in their mind. Having said that, The Wolf Among Us manages to deliver a compelling story, if a bit blase for the fans of the detective genre, which manages to keep you engaged and its structure as a mystery seems to work really well with the now alredy tried-and-true episodic format. Extremely well-realized main character benefits from having relatively diverse dialog options which help define his personality along the way, whether he ends up as a chain-smoking stoic or someone else depending on your choices. Supporting characters succeed at being memorable, with couple of exceptions, and help propel the game further with possible future twists and turns hinted towards by the game's system messages.\n\nIn the end, this is a game bearing Telltale Games' characteristic hallmarks and flair - you know what to expect length-wise, characterization-wise and you're already crossing your fingers for another season. Make it happen.

reviewText:
This is a contender with The Walking Dead: Season 1 for Telltale's best game in my eyes. If one is taking art direction into consideration, this is easily the most beautiful game Telltale has ever released. The stylings are gorgeous, the mood pitch-perfect, and that intro sequence has me wanting a Season 2 for more of them alone.

I wasn't the slightest bit familiar with the Fables universe going into this game, and it would be fair to say my expectations were set very low. That said: I was sold on it by the time Bigby lit his cigarette, the reverb of his lighter flick springboarding into a slick, fantastically atmospheric musical intro sequence.

I experienced a lot of moments in this game like that. Be it the sound, art, writing, or the voice acting (let me shout out Bigby again here); this is an inspired piece of work from top to bottom. I finished episode 5 tonight and the afterglow is incredible.

reviewText: The Wolf Among Us is a Telltale Adventure game in the vein of The Walking Dead series. It takes place in the world of the Fables comics, where characters from myths and fairytales are alive and living in modern-day New York. Through the course of the game, you make choices through dialog trees and point-and-click adventure gameplay, which can cause (mildly) divergent paths throughout the plotline, making the game's experience your own. The story itself deals with a noir-esque mystery, where you take on the role of Sheriff Big B. Wolf, aiming to solve a murder.\n\nThe game, taken as a whole, is very well crafted. Voice acting is top-notch, and there's some rather subtle lore and information spread throughout - it was wholly enjoyable and I highly recommend it. The one negative that I would say about the game is that there are a large number of action sequences which use QTE to resolve themselves, so if QTE are not your cup of tea, that may drag down on your opinion of the game. It's difficult to get into much greater detail without delving into the plot itself, which is the whole point with these games, so I'll leave it at that. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
So this game is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing brilliant.

I still think The Walking Dead ep1 was better overall, however TWAU boasts a much better opening chapter/your choices have a larger impact upon the guaranteed events/the setting allows for some very interesting things you wouldn't be able to try in a post-apoc WD-universe game. I still love Lee/Clem, but playing as the Big Bad Wolf was assuredly just as fantastic.

It's set itself up for a really good sequel - one with a proper plot continuation, that draws heavily from the comics, which are also amazing. The game has loads of iconic moments, and true badassery you can't find in many games nowadays.

Only negative things I'd say:
- You don't appear to be able to get all of the Fables entries/collectables by naturally going through it; aiming for a particular character needs to be broken occassionally if you care about the 100%.
- Because the dialogue you select isn't EXACTLY what Bigby says, if you're not 100% concentrating/reading it several ways, a few accidental choices could be made. :'(
- Due to the nature of only being able to have so many responses, a lot of the time you're really wanting to say something that there just isn't an option for (tho the genre can't really avoid this tbh).
- Episodes 2 and 3 are pretty short, and not as good as the stunning 1, 4, 5 - TellTale appear to have grasped back their quality, after a rough patch (probs coinciding with the GoT/Borderlands/other TWAU eps' release dates/TWDep2/etc).


Overall, buy it... You really have no reason not to; the price is so low when on sale, and although you won't rack as many hours as you will on some other games, each hour will almost always be far more emotional/interesting/etc than far too many other games. I had a lot less hours on this, than I did TWDep1, but it felt just as long - it has none of the walking about to find clues/puzzle solving/long character dialogues that TWD had, and replaces it with much more action/narrative; both are still great. A nice feature that almost replaces the puzzle solving is how you can be wrong - the game openly invites you to guess at suspects/etc, and if you haven't been paying attention to what has unfolded before you, the story can change nicely.

reviewText:
Some of my first and most vital PC gaming experiences, growing up, involved the classic point-and-click adventure. I'll always have a soft spot in my heart for those kind of games. Once again, Telltale games has revitalized the entire genre with The Wolf Among Us.

I purposefully kept a blind ear and eye to every single bit of information/reviews/videos when it came to this game and what it was about, until the moment I could play it for myself. I was more than pleasantly surprised to discover it was based on the comics I have been reading and enjoying for the past few months--The Fables series. And I have to say, it really does the comic book series justice, both in style and character.  But don't worry, even if you've never read the series you can easily delve deeply into the world this game presents.

Who doesn't like a good murder mystery? It's even better when you get to take the role of detective (or in this case, Sheriff), sniffing out clues and interrogating suspects, piecing together evidence bit by bit. In this case, you are none other than the Big Bad Wolf, who has been assigned to bring law and order to Fabletown: a magical and rather grisly place tucked away in New York, where many creatures of legend and fairytale characters have been exiled to live. As you can expect, not everybody plays nicely with each other, and pretty soon things end up bloody.  I love how the game really gives you complete control over your character's personality and detective skills, though it could be frustrating at times when you come to realize something major yourself...only to wait and guide your character to eventually come to the same conclusion.

Most point-and-click adventures let you explore freely and take your time, it's all rather leisurely. And although there is plenty of room to explore around Fabletown, taking your time really isn't an option. At all. To me, though, this only adds to the tension and excitement you feel as the story unfolds. The game is highly cinematic in nature, so that if you step away or stop paying attention for one moment....you could miss a critical clue, lose your sway in a conversation, or worse. You must constantly be on your toes and ready to make decisions that help shape the way your character is perceived and solve the case. Not only that, it makes the game nearly impossible to want to stop playing, and that's a very good thing. I found myself glued to the seat and highly focused for each and every episode of this.

The game reminds me of an old noir crime movie, with plenty of seedy characters, red herrings, blood, sex, brutal fistfights and relentless twists and turns. It's highly intellectual and really forces you to think for yourself, but I guarantee you will always be second-guessing yourself throughout, playing back old conversations and situations to make sure you did the right thing.  After all, the game is filled with varying choices, and it's these nuances that not only add to the first time experience of playing--but also offer replay value.

I won't spoil the end, of course, but I will say only this: If you played the game as intensely as I did, you won't be able to stop thinking about it for at least a few days. And the best kinds of games are the ones that haunt you and stay with you like that, in my opinion.

reviewText: The Wolf Among Us is the shortest Telltale adventure game series I've played so far but it's turned out to be one of my favourites. Its unique setting with downtrodden fairy tale characters living in an 80s New York (courtesy of Bill Willingham's Fables) seems to be a perfect match for an adventure game - or a visual novel with Quick Time Events (which I believe is a more accurate description of Telltale's adventure games from the past couple of years). Is it better than The Walking Dead? I personally think so, but only because I like solving murder mysteries. Both games are good in their own right but while one explores the human condition against a backdrop of zombie apocalypse, the other provides a grittier, seedier epilogue to fairy tale characters we grew up learning about as kids.

reviewText:
The Wolf Among Us  is Telltale's interpretation of the Fables universe, and it is an amazing game.

As a cinematic experience and a prequel to the source material, this game is highly accessible.
While it is rooted in the Point And Click Adventure genre, it abandons the puzzle element
for a more sophisticated dialogue system. What you end up with is not entirely dissimilar to a
film, the story's direction influenced by the choices you make.

There's a real sense of agency in these choices. You take up the role of Bigby Wolf, investigating a murder case as the sheriff of the local community of Fabletown. As you go about your investigation, touching the lives of the various characters you run into, you will see them respond to the calls you make. What do you do when you see a friend break the law? How do you respond when people disrespect you? How far are you willing to go to get answers? These are all questions you will answer through your actions, and the characters respond accordingly.

The cast of characters is vibrant. All of the major characters have a realistic and unique personality, which makes their thoughts and actions easy to relate to, while making them all stand out from the rest in one way or another. This way of writing makes sure that even with a relatively small amount of time spent interacting, you will always have a clear idea of who someone is and why you should or shouldn't like them. The voice acting is also of a very high level. Telltale veterans like Adam Harrington, Erin Yvette, Gavin Hammon and many others bring Fabletown to life in a way that that is unrivaled in the industry.

All in all, The Wolf Among Us is nothing short of a fenomenal experience. With it's accessibility, well written story and impressive characters, this is one game you should not miss out on.

This review was written at a time when all five episodes were released.

reviewText:
Most enjoyable.

I was a bit annoyed that some story elements in the conclusion were unable to be changed despite my efforts/choices, but it highlights the lore in the Fables' universe (which, before this game, I was unaware of)

QTE's are present but not as overbearing as in other titles, characters draw enough empathy to care about them and your choices and the story is a great mix of fantasy and mistery-thriller.

I would have liked at least one more episode to wrap things up though.

As far as performance issues go, I found only one: when transitioning from one chapter to the next the game would get stuck with empty prompts or a frozen camera, but this was easily fixed by going to the main menu and selecting the chapter again. Since this bug only appears at the beginning of the chapter it takes but a few seconds to get back to playing the game.

reviewText:
This is the first Telltale game that I've completed, and it was worth every penny and minute.

The Wolf Among Us has a great story throughout which included very adult and real themes at time, its impossible to not end up feeling emotionally attached to some of the characters. You can either allow Bigby stay as the big bad wolf or try and turn a new leaf with the dialogue and action options, I personally tried to turn over a new leaf but sometimes someone just needed a little threatening.

On top of this the design of the game from menu screen, to each episode of the game, and the credits is lovely. My favourite character designs are Bigby Wolf - the subtley of his changes and his final form are great - and Bloody Mary - her true form design is so good; the sounds accompanying her when walking, and how she shatters. I'm just insanely impressed with how well this is put together.

Its fairly straight forward to complete the game with 100% achievements but there are a few things that you might miss depending on choices you make - some areas you need to pick to go to a certain destinaton first - but there are guides that'll help you figure out what you're missing and which chapters you might need to replay at the end.

reviewText:
Possibly my favorite Telltale game, The Wolf Among Us is a (non canon?) prequel to the fantastic comic series Fables.

Mixing fairy tales, mystery, and the modern mundane world, The Wolf Among Us spins an intruiging tale that draws in the player. The game's art direction is very interesting with a mix of comic style, and cell-shading (in the classic Telltale way), and all the characters are intruging and fun to interact with. I often found myself scrounging for more lore on each character, and as a completionist (albeit with little patience), I found it easy to get all the items and get all the achievements with only a couple replays for a couple chapters.

Although the game gives you choices to make, let's be honest and say that this is Telltale... And we all know how consequential most choices actually are... That said, it's always interesting to see how character react to a-hole Bigby in contrast to good" Bigby.

If you're looking for a relaxing game with nice soundtrack
recommended: and a very enjoyable story. I'd highly recommend this game. I'd also highly recommend reading the original comic if you're looking for more in the Fables universe and good ol' Bigby."

reviewText:
After some major trouble in the homelands of the fairytale characters they flee to the normal (mundy) world of New York City. Here they find out that things are hard and hardly end 'happily ever after'. This is the background of a gritty and dark Telltale adventure where your choices make the story and helped with some quick-time events make this an action adventure too.
The main character is Bigby Wolf, the big bad wolf from the fairytales who is now the sheriff of 'Fabletown' and has to deal with the growing discontent of the fairytale creatures who find it hard to live as 'normal'  people. No one trusts him and everybody is scared of this beast with his bloody history. And then the unrest really starts when a murder is committed. As the story unfolds you discover that this runs way deeper and will influence the very excistence of Fabletown and its inhabitants.

I really enjoyed this story, although I sometimes got frustrated by the quick-time events and the short time-period you are given to make your choices. But the story was so gripping that I finished chapters 3 to 5 in one go.

I highly recommend this game to everyone who like story driven games and I guarentee everyone who has read their fair share of fairytales you'll have fun recognising every character and the way they are portrayed in this modern-day fairytale.

reviewText: This game is supposed to be a prequel to a comic book series called Fables. It is about all sorts of fairy tale characters we know (e.g. Red Riding Hood, Beauty and Beast) who live among us as they were forced to leave their home. In Fabletown (which is part of New York) they try to blend in with the humans (who they call mundies") and for those not having human form it proves to be difficult: an enchantment called "glamour" is a must to change forms
date:
otherwise they are sent to "The Farm" which is not exactly a place any Fable wants to be.

The game takes place in the '80s and the player assumes the control of the Wolf from Red Riding Hood. Big Wolf - or Bigby - acts as the Sheriff of Fabletown and is set out to solve a crime that ended in the death of one of the Fables. He is aided by Snow White and other fairy tale / folklore characters we may or may not recognise.

Now
recommended:
if you have already played a Telltale adventure game Wolf Among Us will be familiar to you:

--- there are a relatively few places where objects can be picked up or interacted with (we have the option to investigate our surroundings while the rest of the game gives us a mainly film-like experience with lots of cutscenes and dialogues)
--- your inventory does not really get full of items and if an item can be used with another one in the environment the game tells you that
--- there are lots of characters to speak with and during conversations you have a limited time to pick an answer - these affect the relationship you have with these people and a choice can often have dire consequences
--- due to the availability of choices a 2nd or even a 3rd walkthrough can easily yield you new results (the changes can even affect the end game)
--- during action sequences quick-time-events are common but the pop-up buttons are easy to hit - this is not a difficult game (the main idea here is the immersion)

Wolf Among Us sports an interesting story and it entertains you from start to finish while you try to find the killer of Fabletown. Since prior to this I played the Walking Dead series I can make a comparison between the two: Wolf has more action sequences and while there's drama it certainly is less emotional. Oh
hoursPlayed: and make no mistake: just because it is about fairy tale characters gore and violence (along with cursing) is common.\n\nFor fans of Telltale adventure games this is a recommended title - for newcomers it's also worth checking."

reviewText:
Most enjoyable.

I was a bit annoyed that some story elements in the conclusion were unable to be changed despite my efforts/choices, but it highlights the lore in the Fables' universe (which, before this game, I was unaware of)

QTE's are present but not as overbearing as in other titles, characters draw enough empathy to care about them and your choices and the story is a great mix of fantasy and mistery-thriller.

I would have liked at least one more episode to wrap things up though.

As far as performance issues go, I found only one: when transitioning from one chapter to the next the game would get stuck with empty prompts or a frozen camera, but this was easily fixed by going to the main menu and selecting the chapter again. Since this bug only appears at the beginning of the chapter it takes but a few seconds to get back to playing the game.

reviewText:
This is the first Telltale game that I've completed, and it was worth every penny and minute.

The Wolf Among Us has a great story throughout which included very adult and real themes at time, its impossible to not end up feeling emotionally attached to some of the characters. You can either allow Bigby stay as the big bad wolf or try and turn a new leaf with the dialogue and action options, I personally tried to turn over a new leaf but sometimes someone just needed a little threatening.

On top of this the design of the game from menu screen, to each episode of the game, and the credits is lovely. My favourite character designs are Bigby Wolf - the subtley of his changes and his final form are great - and Bloody Mary - her true form design is so good; the sounds accompanying her when walking, and how she shatters. I'm just insanely impressed with how well this is put together.

Its fairly straight forward to complete the game with 100% achievements but there are a few things that you might miss depending on choices you make - some areas you need to pick to go to a certain destinaton first - but there are guides that'll help you figure out what you're missing and which chapters you might need to replay at the end.

reviewText:
The Wolf Among Us is a game I never really expected much from, but was completely blown away. I will even admittedly say that I may have even enjoyed this series more than TellTale's famous The Walking Dead series.

--Final thoughts at the bottom--

Gameplay
The game play is reminiscent to TellTales other adventure games. You progress through the story by investigating areas to find useful information or a way of proceding to the next area. Their is no complex puzzles or anything to get you stuck as the game is heavily story related so it tries to keep you progressing.

Most of the gameplay is about carefully choosing your response to conversations or story event where you must choose between doing X or doing Y. Quicktime events fill in alot of the action parts and add to the intensity.

Graphics
The cell shaded art style fits perfectly into this world they have created. The characters are well drawn and animated, some feel very recognizable. The facial movements and body movements look good, however some people still seem to walk like they have a stick up their butt(This is an issue I have with all TellTale games).

The world they have created sets the perfect setting for how the story takes place. The amount of detail they went into on some of the level design is very well done, even in places you arent around for very long. Its nice to see them still put the detail in to make this feel like a live breathing world.

Audio
The sound is done very well in The Wolf Among Us. The background noise and ambience was well done. The music is superb for the style they are going for in this game. The theme song kinda reminds me of Farcry 3: Blood Dragon music. The ingame music was very good at setting the mood for the events happening as well as for the areas you were exploring.

The voice over work is phenomenal and is what brings this story to life. The voices chosen for each character fit their rolls perfectly. Not once did I hear any voice that I thought to myself that doesn't fit". The emotions are portrayed very well through their voices and sucks the player into the story. Top notch voice acting all around.

Story
The story is where this game really shines. I must admit I was never really interested in this game

reviewText:
And here we go again, another fantastic game by the creators of Game Of The Year winning The Walking Dead. This follows the Sheriff of Fabletown. We know him as The Big Bad Wolf but here he is called Bigby Wolf. We follow him to uncover the murder of a fable.

What do I think of this game?
I think this is better, darker, more mature than the Walking Dead series. The voice acting is superb, the environment is engrossing to the story line, the story is more in depth then Lee and Clemintines survival of the Walking Dead, in search of her parents. What is better is that this game is a prequel to the comics, so you can go  spend over 200 dollars on the entire collection! No seriously, don't do that. Anyway, telltale has provided us with another fantastic game.

Do I expect a Season 2?
I would love one but since this is a prequel you'd have to read the comics first then play the next season, unless they do it straight after the end of Episode 5, and 5 does leave you on the edge of your seat. So yeah, I expect one but don't have your hopes up.

reviewText:
And here we go again, another fantastic game by the creators of Game Of The Year winning The Walking Dead. This follows the Sheriff of Fabletown. We know him as The Big Bad Wolf but here he is called Bigby Wolf. We follow him to uncover the murder of a fable.

What do I think of this game?
I think this is better, darker, more mature than the Walking Dead series. The voice acting is superb, the environment is engrossing to the story line, the story is more in depth then Lee and Clemintines survival of the Walking Dead, in search of her parents. What is better is that this game is a prequel to the comics, so you can go  spend over 200 dollars on the entire collection! No seriously, don't do that. Anyway, telltale has provided us with another fantastic game.

Do I expect a Season 2?
I would love one but since this is a prequel you'd have to read the comics first then play the next season, unless they do it straight after the end of Episode 5, and 5 does leave you on the edge of your seat. So yeah, I expect one but don't have your hopes up.

reviewText:
The Wolf Among Us is inspired by the Fable comics. Let's speak clearly: it's a great hommage to this comics series, both respectful and capable of adding to the original. The game is an adventure game that works as a serial, with strong characters and a solid thriller story. The game's not about difficult enigmas our strange environment but it's more about trying to tell a story in an unprecedented format (except for The Walking Dead game). And it does a great job at it. Really, being the main character, choosing your answers, your way around and chasing who you think is the suspect has a real impact on the way you enjoy the story. Once again, a masterpiece for Telltame Games.

Compared to The Walking Dead

Though very similar to The Walking Dead (which I enjoyed), this video games series seems better to me. Despite its link to childhood themes (fairy tales coming to life), it eems more mature and works around topics like : taking responsability for your action or passion versus reason. It sure isn't as much of an emotional roller coaster as TWD. More of a philosophical tale. Besides, this one definetely has more interactivity than TWD

reviewText:
It's hard to talk about The Wolf Among Us without comparing it to its older brother The Walking Dead as they practically share the same game style. Tell Tale did a great revamp with the point and click adventure genre and what truly shines for their newer instalments are the players dialogue and action inputs that affect that story as you progress.

Playing as Fable sheriff Bigby Wolf (The big bad wolf) you have a bad reputation for having a temper and violent tendencies. The games theme is based around judgement of character and lets you choose to whether live up to your tenacity or redeem yourself in the folks that you serve and protect.

Always thinking about your actions and seeing your consequences unfold blurs the lines of good and bad and that's what makes TWAU really stand out. Will you assert your authority? Show remorse? Keep your cool? or unleash who you really are?

Solve the case, help clean up Fable town. And show your true side.... Your bite maybe worse than your bark.

I have to start by confessing my dirty little secret - I am a huge fan of graphic novels, and the Fables series sits firmly in second place of my favourites list (right behind Neil Gaiman's Sandman series). I was therefore excited and nervous in equal shares about picking up and playing this game - these are characters I have known and loved for several years, thrown into a new medium. Let's face it: I was either going to love it or hate it.

I loved it. I've just finished it - around 10 hours of pretty much straight through gameplay. I was hooked the whole time. I'm already thinking about booting it up to play it again. What if I'd made X choice instead of Y? What if I hadn't ripped someone's throat out? What if I had thrown that guy down a well? Etc., etc.,...!

reviewText:
With the Wolf Among Us Telltale have delivered another brilliant interactive story. This game plays similarly to the Walking Dead in that it's a point and click game where you have various dialogue choices as well as other choices to make that effect the story of the game. The Wolf Among Us is based on the Fable series of comics. It's set in a part of New York inhabited by the characters from the nursery rhymes and fairytales such as  Snow White and  Mr.Toad. All these mythical characters had to move to our world after there Homeland was destroyed.

It sounds like it might be a story for children but anything but with the characters inhabiting a gritty dark world where they have to deal with inequality and poverty and the politics that go with it. In the game you play Bigby (The Big Bad Wolf) who is the sheriff of Fabletown. He gets embroiled in a murder case and indoing so finds himself caught up in the politics of Fabletown itself as he tries to solve the crime.

As already said the gameplay is very similar to the Walking Dead as is the comic book style of animation which looks great. The games main strength is it's story which i found enthralling and it really hooked me in. The characters in this game are brilliant as well and you'll meet a lot of memorable characters from the fairytales you would have heard as a child. The great thing is the characters are all very realistic in that they have their own problems like being alcholics or struggling to pay rent and feel a lot more fleshed out than the more 2 dimensional characters they are in the old fairytales.

The Good:
-Fantastic story with some really characters
-Game looks nice with that comic book style of animation
-All episodes are released now so no waiting a month or two for the next episode.
-Game has decent replay value as it's worth playing again but making different choices to see how it changes the story.

The Bad:
-Not a lot really. I suppose the only one i can think of is that the gameplay is identical to that off the Walking Dead. Wold have been nice to see some new ideas introduced in this area.

Overall I loved this game. More than i enjoyed the Walking Dead. I know this game will mostly appeal to WD fans but this is really great in it's own right and should be a must-buy for anyone looking for a game with a great story. Especially now all the episodes have been released. 10/10

reviewText:
If you love interactive stories with a good pitch, in which the choices you make have an impact, this game is for you. I have yet to read the comics so I won't venture on the subject of how faithful it is to the source material, but as a standalone, it's good. The ambience is that of a film noir, and the dark take on fairytales characters is a pleasure. It's exciting to place them and their tales, and see what the creators made of them. Sheriff Bigbie - the hero - is a bit of an archetype: brutal, taciturn, with his rough edges, his cigarettes and his bourbon, but it's one I enjoy.

Prepare to investigate some gruesome murders and dive into the darkness of Fabletown.

Careful if you're operating with an AZERTY keyboard, make sure to configure it as a QWERTY before starting, as (as far as I know, but I didn't look far into it) you cannot change the commands and part of the game relies on your ability to press the right key quickly.

Imagine a TellTale version of L.A. Noire set in a fantasy based world. This is the most accurate description of this game. It's definitely a gritty and dark Detective Noir flick but in a game format.

I intially bought this game during last year's sale just because the Steam sales were average and this was one of the few games that went on sale that I didn't own and felt like giving a shot. This was probably one of the best decisions I could make. This game has made it into my top 5 games of all times.

The game has intense action scenes, legitimate choices that end up changing everyone perception of you in the world of Fable - whether you're The Big Bad Wolf, or the misunderstood tough guy. Wolf Among Us keeps all elements of a great mystery, just when you think you know WHODUNNIT - the stakes are changed. Every episode builds completely towards the ending, as there are no filler episodes, each is filled with teeth grinding suspense, heart pounding action, and a weird romance between the main character and Faith. I enjoy the fact that this game rarely tends to hold your hand and if you fail in doing something then you are subtley pointed in the right direction.

One of the biggest issues in this game is the choices, in the sense that some are actually pretty hard to make. I've spent probably about an hour all together with the game paused and me sitting back in my chair in contemplation of what to do because this game really does test your morality, it gives you [The Right Choice] and [What Should Be Done] simultaneously. After beating the game I saw myself sitting here biting my lip hoping I made the right choices for the citizens of Fable.

As stated above, this game earns a full two thumbs up from me. It is definitely in my top 5 and I recommend EVERYONE to purchase this, even if not on sale. It is worth it.

reviewText:
Cutting right to the chase. Buy it. Favorite TellTale game to date.  And that's considering I played their Walking Dead game. Film noir meets a mysterious point-and-click adventure within the world of Fables. If you liked Walking Dead, this is much the same thing, but mystery and replacing the gun with, well, the wolf among us.

...please don't let that line steer you away. I will say, tiny con. If you want this game, get it for the price of $15, which is three episodes. Episode 2 is, regrettably, the low point of the game. Does that make it bad? No, by no means. It just does not shine in comparison to the others. Episode 4 falls flat in the same way, but manages to learn from the Ep. 2 mistake to make it at least a tiny bit better. Effectively, you'd be paying for the price of three really fantastic episodes: the start, the middle, and the finish, while the other two episodes act as building blocks so that the next episode is entirely that much better.

tl;dr - Seriously, buy it. It's flaws are omittable because this game is a fantastic 7-10 hour experience, and while I would reccommend it on sale, I would suggest to buy it at any price to support TellTale for their fantastic work. I'll give it a damn 11/10.

reviewText:
The Wolf Among Us is, without a doubt, one of the best games I've played in a long while. It was dark, immersive, and perfectly paced, with a stellar setting, and great characters.

If you've played any other Telltale games, you know what the score is: the majority of the game is picking what to say, to whom, and when, with the odd quick time event thrown in for good measure. Fortunately, the dialogue in The Wolf Among Us is almost flawless, the voice acting superb, and the QTE well-utilised - much more so than in TWD, for example.

The game builds slowly, with the first few episodes heaping on characters, clues, and difficult choices. It burns quite slowly in this way for a while, leaving you chasing a growing number of suspects, all the while unsure if you're actually measuring up to the task before you. The hardest decisions you make will be the ones that are only slightly different shades of grey, and, for most of the game, it's never obvious which is the right" choice to make.

This all changes in the season's finale
date: though. After chasing your own tail all over Fabletown
recommended: the final episode is an explosion of revelations and action. The rising tension cultivated throughout the previous episodes gets shattered and replaced with some of the toughest decisions of all
hoursPlayed: and a climax that is bittersweet at best. Whilst you definitely feel you've earned /a/ victory
voteText: it certainly isn't easy or pain-free
helpfulPercent: and you're still left in the dark as to whether or not you did the right thing as the credits roll. But that's fine - the beauty of the game is that it concludes in a satisfying way without giving you an answer.\n\nShould you play The Wolf Among Us? I don't think even Bigby would struggle over the right answer on this one. It's a stylish

reviewText:
If you love interactive stories with a good pitch, in which the choices you make have an impact, this game is for you. I have yet to read the comics so I won't venture on the subject of how faithful it is to the source material, but as a standalone, it's good. The ambience is that of a film noir, and the dark take on fairytales characters is a pleasure. It's exciting to place them and their tales, and see what the creators made of them. Sheriff Bigbie - the hero - is a bit of an archetype: brutal, taciturn, with his rough edges, his cigarettes and his bourbon, but it's one I enjoy.

Prepare to investigate some gruesome murders and dive into the darkness of Fabletown.

Careful if you're operating with an AZERTY keyboard, make sure to configure it as a QWERTY before starting, as (as far as I know, but I didn't look far into it) you cannot change the commands and part of the game relies on your ability to press the right key quickly.

reviewText:
The Wolf Among Us is, without a doubt, one of the best games I've played in a long while. It was dark, immersive, and perfectly paced, with a stellar setting, and great characters.

If you've played any other Telltale games, you know what the score is: the majority of the game is picking what to say, to whom, and when, with the odd quick time event thrown in for good measure. Fortunately, the dialogue in The Wolf Among Us is almost flawless, the voice acting superb, and the QTE well-utilised - much more so than in TWD, for example.

The game builds slowly, with the first few episodes heaping on characters, clues, and difficult choices. It burns quite slowly in this way for a while, leaving you chasing a growing number of suspects, all the while unsure if you're actually measuring up to the task before you. The hardest decisions you make will be the ones that are only slightly different shades of grey, and, for most of the game, it's never obvious which is the right" choice to make.

This all changes in the season's finale
date: though. After chasing your own tail all over Fabletown
recommended: the final episode is an explosion of revelations and action. The rising tension cultivated throughout the previous episodes gets shattered and replaced with some of the toughest decisions of all
hoursPlayed: and a climax that is bittersweet at best. Whilst you definitely feel you've earned /a/ victory
voteText: it certainly isn't easy or pain-free
helpfulPercent: and you're still left in the dark as to whether or not you did the right thing as the credits roll. But that's fine - the beauty of the game is that it concludes in a satisfying way without giving you an answer.\n\nShould you play The Wolf Among Us? I don't think even Bigby would struggle over the right answer on this one. It's a stylish

votesTotal: and often-violent look at fairy tale characters in our world
votesFunny: and it's more than worth the asking price."

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
7/10

The Good:
Just as The Walking Dead, this game is a point and click adventure. The story is interesting, entertaining and morally ambigious. It is how the player reacts to the moral questions that decides where the story is going.

The Bad:
One of the biggest shortcomings of this game is its limited interactivity. Sometimes you seemingly just listen to conversations and watch events unfold for minutes at a time, without having the chance to effect change. Worse, even when given the chance to make a choice, it is often only cosmetic. The other problem I had were the numerous quick time events, they felt simplistic, and a contrived way to create tension.

The Verdict:

The story and moral choices are what makes this game entertaining. Though the game struggles to offer meaningful interactivity in many situations, and is a tad heavy on the quick time events. I hope Tell Tale Games can look to their excellent Walking Dead Season I to improve upon that in the next season for Wolf Among Us. Don't think its worth the full price, but definitely worth a consideration when it is on sale.

reviewText:
The Wolf Among Us pretty much caught me by surprise. Not sure how I managed to avoid any advertising / hype, but after Telltale's previously excellent zombie adventure, I didn't need to consider for long.

The first thing that struck me was how good the game looked. The comic book-styling seen in The Walking Dead is taken notch further, with heavier contrast and brighter colors, painting very vivid film noir-look, accompanied with appropriately smoky and moody soundtrack. Easily the most stylized adventure by Telltale so far.

Most observant eye may catch some familiar animation frames from TWD, but such detail is lost to the imaginative and lively character cast. It's this godforsaken bunch of familiar storybook characters on the junky Brooklyn backdrop that I really started growing into. The trope isn't especially new, with McGee's Alice and also Batman Arkham series having played with the idea, but instead of gothically twisted version of themselves, being thrown in the middle of Chinatown(the movie) works itself to much juicier drama (and healthy dose of brutal violence).

I wasn't previously familiar with the series, but the game does good job introducing you to the universe, with both pacing and further reading. Although the writing in the game is as serious as any good noire story is, it does leave some space for character's to self realise on the absurdity of their existance, where a bunch of comedy is derived from.

The gameplay is familiar 80% dialogue with some QTE'ish action thrown in. The action scenes seemed to take a bit more cues from the yesteryear's Jurassic Park, but kept the rumble short and sweet. Kudos for the game to cleverly disguise a puzzle in form of dialogue I didn't realise I was doing until towards the end.

As the end credits rolled, only thing I felt bad about was that I didn't wait long enough, that I could've just hopped straight to the next episode.

reviewText:
The wolf among us is a detective game, but unlike most; while you certainly need to connect the dots, the evidence you get is fairly easy to uncover and your character can pretty much supplement any 'connecting the dots' you failed to do. No, 'The Wolf Among Us' is more a story about your choices and how you mold this world you're in with these choices.

The story is set in modern day New York City, primarily in the Bronx from what I remember, where the characters of fairy tale stories have moved after their former residences became obsolete with modernisation. This secret community of fables is referred to as 'Fabletown', and you, the Big Bad Wolf from the story about the three little pigs, are the sheriff. No one likes you, mostly due to what you've done previously in fairy tales.

Choices you make directly impact how the game plays out; there may be two leads you need to follow but only have time for one, or perhaps you need to choose whether you wish to spare a character or not. The leads present themselves naturally through story progression, but nearly always you're forced to make touch choices as to whether you will follow a lead or not. Parts of the story will open or close themselves depending on which route you take; following one lead may or may not help you solve the mystery, and may just bring more questions than answers.

By the very nature of the game, character development was excellent, with characters changing dynamically throughout the series; the art style was memorable and does not age easily, looking fantastic even now. The sound also stays with me even now, fitting the theme of the story very, very well.

'The Wolf Among Us' was a rollercoaster ride for me, and was a memorable game, easily one of my favorites to have played.

reviewText: While not as DEVASTATINGLY EMOTIONAL (thank god) as the Walking Dead series, this is one cool as hell mystery that combines some very mature noir sensibilities with fairy tale characters. That alone is pretty much enough to sell it to me, and it delivers on the promise of dark, gritty twists on classic characters while also involving you deeply in the world around as it unveils itself right along with the mystery you're tracking.\n\nIt's mature and has plenty of adult themes, but it doesn't indulge in these things just for the sake of them. The darker content fits very well with the sleazy underworld it's showing to you, and the writing and acting are consistently excellent from start to finish. Mystery, black humour, sudden brutal violence, and a great cast of weird, slightly crazy characters makes this one of the most enjoyable worlds to dive into in recent years. Telltale really knows how to capture a fictional setting well, so if you're into point and click adventures with emphasis on story over puzzles, you can't go wrong with this one.

reviewText: The Wolf Among Us follow's the Telltale interactive storyformula that we've come to know and mostly enjoy over the years. Basic on the Fables comic series, which I'm not directly familiar with, the story has you in control of Bigby Wolf (Big Bad) Sheriff of Fabletown as you get to the bottom of a murder mystery involving many other famous characters from children's stories and sides of them you haven't seen before. You have the usual Telltale dialogue choices, which usually can be narrowed down to whether you're a good cop or reverting back to your Big Bad Wolf days of intimidation and violence. I didn't feel that the payoff for a lot of these decisions was all that interesting, which is no surprise with Telltale's history. But the overall story is enjoyable thanks especially to the interesting atmosphere of the characters and town. I want to note that I did have a surprising number of crashes during parts of the game, and lost progress occasionally, but with PC gaming it's hard to say whether it was the game's fault or not. All in all, definitely worth a play.

reviewText:
First of all, this game is a Telltale game, so your expectations must be about story, dialogue, an absorbing and immersive world and non-frustrating QTEs. And this game doesn't fail to deliver any of the above. As someone who also played BAck to the Future, TWD and Sam&Max, this title would be my first choice as the best game of Telltale. Here is a little list of pros and cons to explain myself better:

Pros:     Great storyline and characters
Absorbing world
Rare but well-done fight scenes
Great artistic design
Ability to choose
Polished and bug-free
QTEs not over done
Overall well-paced
Cons:     Clunky controls as always
Not so often but some QTEs feel clunky too
Some choices don't affect the game, at least for this season
Inventory system has no usage
No puzzles to solve
As I said, imo this game is the best so far delivered by Telltale despite its flaws. When you finish one episode you can't wait for the next, and after finishing the whole season you really want a new season to get more of it.

reviewText:
This was like a 7 hour long interactive movie about a sheriff caught up in a dark murder mystery.  It's dark, gritty, violent, and well written.  As soon as the game starts within the first 5 minutes, you really get an idea of how the tone for the entire game is going to be.  The characters are all well written, and the voice acting is well done all around.

As you go throuth the games 5 episodes, you will be forced to make a lot of choices, and often times the game doesn't give you a lot of time to think which makes the siutations that much more tense.  These decisions have very serious consequences that last over the course of the entire game.  You will find youself regretting choices, and wondering what could have happened if you had chosen another course of action.  At the end of each chapter the game gives you a break down telling you what % of the players made the same choices you did which gives an interesting point of view.

The game ending for me at least was very satisfying, maybe if I had chosen differently I would have felt differently, but this is really an amazing game overall, with potential replay value in going back to replay the story and make different chioces just to see how the decision have a ripple effect on other events.  An amazing game, highly recommended.

reviewText:
I recommend this game, but with reservations.

I have to start by admitting, I really am not interested or familiar with Fairy Tales ‚Äì and this game, or ‚Äútale‚Äù, does a good job at making sure that that isn't a disadvantage.  The graphics work well with this environment, and should even work with APU graphics.  As with other Tell Tale titles everything is polished, works well, and thought out.  It is a well engineered game.

The last episode is really disappointing.  The boss battle is laughable the way it ends, I'll spare you the spoiler details, but you will laugh.  After the boss battle the game ends with about 30 minutes of talking with various characters as the story wraps it self up.  It was very anti-climatic.  The second, third, and fourth episodes were the best.  The first and fifth were slow and uninteresting.

Overall, The Wolf Among us can feel like a chore.  A bit like watching a movie that started good but lost your interest.  But the middle of the series was so good I have to recommend this game.  Its worth a play.  Many of the decisions that you have to make will leave you with regret, and that's what makes Tell Tale games great.

reviewText:
Do you like games with awesome storytelling? Do you like making choices that affect your story? Playing Cluedo, or any other detective in that matter?
Did you enjoy fairytales as a child? Always wanted to talk to the Magic Mirror (Snow White) yourself? Have you always wanted to see the Little Mermaid naked?

Then this is the game for you! TellTale once again wins big time by delivering an astounding game, with a very original concept, in which fairytale characters have trouble adjusting to the 'real' world, after being forced out of their story ones. The 'Fables', as they're called deal with divorces, anxiety, money problems and severe depressions.

It's like the gritty, dark part of your childhood that was hidden away, but for which you are old enough now, and this all set in a murder-solving overhaul.

Apparently, not in every fairytale they live happily ever after.
But seriously. This game is awesome. Check it out.

8.5/10

reviewText:
First of all, this game is a Telltale game, so your expectations must be about story, dialogue, an absorbing and immersive world and non-frustrating QTEs. And this game doesn't fail to deliver any of the above. As someone who also played BAck to the Future, TWD and Sam&Max, this title would be my first choice as the best game of Telltale. Here is a little list of pros and cons to explain myself better:

Pros:     Great storyline and characters
Absorbing world
Rare but well-done fight scenes
Great artistic design
Ability to choose
Polished and bug-free
QTEs not over done
Overall well-paced
Cons:     Clunky controls as always
Not so often but some QTEs feel clunky too
Some choices don't affect the game, at least for this season
Inventory system has no usage
No puzzles to solve
As I said, imo this game is the best so far delivered by Telltale despite its flaws. When you finish one episode you can't wait for the next, and after finishing the whole season you really want a new season to get more of it.

votesFunny: but you generally don't need to manually drag objects to use them in the environment; special context prompts pop automatically when needed so you don't waste time with trial and error.  Fights and action sequences are quick-time events
commentsCount: sometimes with "did you remember which door the bad guy used" challenges
column16: but most of your time is spent watching cutscenes and making choices in menus.\n\nIf you haven't played a Telltale game of this sort
column17: dialogue usually gives you up to four choices and a realistic but lenient time limit.  Bigby is a deeply interesting character who genuinely wants to do the right thing for a community that isn't always honest or trusting

column21: but it's worth noting that a few isolated sections feel railroaded for the sake of drama.\n\nMany of the most interesting aspects of this role-playing come in the form of Sheriff Bigby's adherence to Fabletown law
column22: which makes logical/pragmatic sense but often interferes with the day-to-day lives of the community

column24: but the game maintains its morally gray atmosphere by making pleasing everybody impossible.\n\nYou're arguably better off the less you know about the comics
column25: because as a prequel
column26: some of the choices in The Wolf Among Us are consequential to how the game plays out but are rendered moot very early in the books.  You meet a wide variety of fictional and supernatural characters whose interpretations and stories (such as how Beauty and the Beast are getting along
column27: which ties into the well-focused plot) feel very adult without coming across as unsuitably 'edgy.'  The story gently introduces the rules of the setting and the attributes of its characters as it goes
column28: and the most interesting thing about this magical community is how utterly realistic it feels
column29: such that you might not notice some of the more fantastic aspects until stray lines of dialogue point them out.\n\nGraphic content is usually handled well: some fights and other scenes are intensely and shockingly gory (ever set a protuding bone via QTE?)
column30: and the sexual content and its impacts on the storyline are introspective and often disturbing enough to keep from feeling like needless fan service.  The language and--if you're not used to this from the story universe--the smoking seem much more gratuitous but are probably the dialogue's biggest "flaws
column31:
so to speak.  Performances are astonishingly well done all around, especially from the few child characters, and some characters feel more likable/less standoffish here than they do in the early Fables volumes.

The characters themselves are generally everything except boring: admirable, treacherous, cynical, rage-inducing, sympathetic, admirable, heartless, psychotic, selfish, perverted, resourceful, and even funny on a scant few occasions (often more than one of these at different times) in what is otherwise a very serious tale.  You'll be encouraged to feel a wide variety of emotions, usually without feeling like the story is stretching for or depending on them.  You'll probably have your heart broken more than once, and while the story has its share of twists, the journey and the conclusion feel satisfying even as the first episode is arguably the best and probably the longest (about two hours when the whole set took me roughly six) and most informative of the five.

At the end of all episodes except the last, there's a TV show-style epilogue that sets up the events of the next installment, and each episode shows you how your choices compared to other players', no matter whether a given dilemma was popularly difficult to resolve or wound up heavily tilted toward one outcome.  You can revisit individual scenes in an episode--the game will note when this overwrites your progress--so you don't have to replay the entire thing to see different outcomes, fill up the secrets gallery, or recall how a certain moment played out.  The characters have their own little biographies that are well worth reading, even as some of these showcase the same events in very different lights, and these segue well into the books if you do (and in my opinion should) go on to read those.

With a wonderful and thoughtful story designed to appeal to adults who can accept its mature and intense subject matter, incredible art design that easily looks as good as the comic it's based on, and plenty of replay value (even if you can't bear to play Bigby as dim or 'evil'), The Wolf Among Us is a more than worthy entry into the Fables universe.

reviewText: TWAU is overall a good game, but it ends up being a big step down from the quality of Walking Dead Season 1. The first episode is actually its strongest, with a great blend of a colorful cast of characters, some nice investigation, a strong noir atmosphere, and the ability to miss out things due to the choices you make. Sadly the game never really follows up that well from such a great opening, though Episode 3 gets mighty close. The atmosphere is still fantastic but the writing and gameplay waver. The characters eventually devolve into being dumb petty ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s, which to be fair is accurate to the comics, but it‚Äôs disappointing because Telltale seemed to be not doing that in the beginning. Investigation and interactivity is reduced to minimum post Episode 3 and your choices tend to not be taken in account that well. Plus the ending can end up be anti-climatic and kind of pants on head stupid if you don‚Äôt make the right choices.\n\nTWAU pretty much ended up in the same boat with TWD Season 2 in that its rather clear to me that after the lead designers of TWD Season 1 left the company Telltale is really struggling to get that magic back. Regardless, TWAU despite its flaws is still well worth playing.

reviewText: It's not really the murder mystery that makes me keep playing The Wolf Among Us. reviewText:
I'm conflicted about The Wolf Among Us. I did enjoy the game and its story, but I feel like the pros and cons evened out

Pros:
- I loved Bigby. I thought he was an excellent protagonist. One of my big gripes with games is when the main character isn't likeable. Bigby is a misunderstood bad guy turned good, and I think it worked well. The choices in the game also let you tailor Bigby to the kind of sheriff you want him to be.
- It's a classic Telltale game. Episodic, story rich, and has choices you can make in the game.
- The end of every episode left me wanting more. Luckily I bought the game after all the episodes came out.
- Even though the game's idea isn't an original one, I still loved it. Fabled characters trying to adapt to the real world.
- Wonderful voiceovers

Cons:
- Even though I fell in love with Bigby, I disliked pretty much every other character except Toad and his son. I don't know if that is Telltale's fault or the comics, but I literally didn't care about most of the cast of characters.
- The story kind of fell apart toward the end. It just got weird, and I felt it went downhill once Bloody Mary and the Crooked Man started playing a role. Also, Bloody Mary is probably one of the worst enemies I've ever witnessed in a game.
- The illusion of choice: your choices in the game don't affect the story at all. The game hardly adapts at all to the choices you make.

I say buy this game, but don't have high expectations.

Also, there are no jump scares.

reviewText:
As you make your way through the dialogue options The Wolf Among us, the game periodically give you little notes about how your choices affect the story and the other characters. A little alert might pop up to tell you something like:

<!> You told the truth

<!> You connected the evidence

<!> Snow will remember that you took her side

Of course, a more honest alert might sound more like this:

<i> Your decision has been carefully recorded for posterity and immediately flushed down the toilet

Nothing you decide in this game matters, which wouldn't be a huge deal except for the fact that decision making is the sole game mechanic. It's tough to give players real choices because it requires a lot more content for the same amount of play time. Other games have run into this issue and some have found innovative solutions.

The Stanley Parable leaned right into it, making the very concept of player agency part of the story. Gone Home, a game in which literally everything that happened happened before the the protagonist even entered the narrative, built uncertainty and used environmental storytelling keep the player engaged. Wolf unfortunately has no tricks up its sleeve to balance its series of pointless choices."

Maybe the biggest problem isn't that the choices aren't meaningful
date: it's that the game won't let you forget how meaningless they are for even one second. Between chapters it asks the player to sit through a recap of the previous chapter and a preview of the next
recommended: both of which serve as reminders of how linear and immutable the plot is. It's as if the game wants to constantly remind you about all of the events that are going to happen no matter what you do.\n\nIt doesn't help that the plot sometimes feels like an arbitrary string of red herrings and unconvincing fake-outs. We may see a character shot in the chest in one scene
hoursPlayed: only to to be told in the next that they're fine because of magic or whatever. In a fictional universe where the rules of magic are never totally spelled out

reviewText: Firstly, this game is a must-play for fans of Fables. As a person who has been collecting Fables trades for years it was pretty great to see the characters fully animated and voiced. Also the setting in this game brought me way back to the very first Fables story; in the comics Bigby has come pretty far away from being the noir detective that he started out as, but playing The Wolf Among Us zapped me right back to those days in a really good way.\n\nThis is the first Telltale game I've played that's structured like this, and to tell the truth it isn't so much a game. It's more of an interactive experience or a visual novel, seeing as there is no way to lose. Even if you make mistakes" along the way you will still be pulled through to the end. Just like real life things come to an end whether you get stuck or not. I like this style of Adventure game because of those very reasons; since the game is built more around the main character's social interactions than solving obtuse puzzles
date: finishing conversations and examining everything becomes a priority.\n\nThe writing in this game is probably it's most blairing selling point. It starts out being very cut-and-dry
recommended: with the backbone of the story being interesting but not something that seems like it would unfurl into a five episode adventure. But I was delightfully surprised by how much more invested I became with each episode I played
hoursPlayed: and by how cleverly each episode led into the next. It's got a great sense of itself
voteText: and the way the writers eerily reveal each facet of the mystery at a steady gait made me anxious and suspenseful over each unreleased episode.\n\nOne of the most important features of any game for me is immersion. How easily I become immersed in a video game dictacts how long it will hold my interest. Even though The Wolf Among Us is about an established character with a very strong voice

reviewText: The Wolf Among Us is a well crafted story wrapped in mystery, presented in Telltale's graphic style of cell-shading and point-and-click mechanic system. Through dialogue, scene investigation, and the occasional fight scene, I experienced a world that is well thought out (thanks to its source material), endlessly intriguing, and just plain gorgeous. The use of fairy tale characters and myths sets the stage for light familiarity with all of the characters, but turns your expectations for nearly every character on its head. The characters feel less like beasts and princesses and more like people who live in the real-world that is sprikled with principles of a fantasy story, which makes for an incredibly realistic experience of characterization and conversations between characters in an otherwise impossible setting.\n\nThis game may certainly not be for everyone, but I would most definitely recommend it to any individual looking for an alternative experience in gaming that is combined with the quality of a cable television series. I'm excited to play through the game a second time to discover what will occur differently upon making different decisions. I can only hope that a second season will be released sooner rather than later so I may lose myself once again in Fabletown to unravel more enigmas and to learn what it means to be human from the wolf among us.

reviewText:
The Wolf Among Us is based on the DC (Vertigo) comic series Fables.
The plot involves fairy tale characters living in a modern day city. Your main character Bigby Wolf has to investigate a series of gruesome murders linking to someone targeting fairy tale creatures. What unfolds is a conspiracy that will shake the foundations of their world.

I love TellTale Games! Therefore i might be biased. But in all honesty, this is a damn good game.
The question is should you buy it?

Well, it depends on what you are looking for in a game. I personally love games for their storylines and this game gets top marks for that. The film noir-esque atmosphere, the design and environments all work in the game's favor and build an atmosphere that really complements the game's story.

But, the question still remains. What do you look for in a game.
Gameplay comprises of Quick time events and some point and click style stuff. You pick dialogue choices which influence the story.

For those of you familiar with TTG's formula, this is nothing new. For those of you who come in expecting puzzles, you will be disappointed.
This is more akin to a √ßhoose your own adventure book' or an interactive movie than a classic point and click game.
For me, that is not a problem. The story was epic and satisfying. The characters felt alive. The action sequences well paced and your decisions can have a real impact (even on the survival of some characters).

Bottomline:

If you are familiar with TTG's formula and like it, or if you are looking for a game with a good story or you are a fan of the original comic series, Get the game

However if you are looking for a puzzle laden point and click game than this is not what it is.

The game has a fair bit of replayability, just to see what different outcomes you can get, which people you can save.

My Recommendation: Buy it!

reviewText:
So, I just finished this game, a couple of hours ago, then I got up. Went to the kitchen, and poured myself a big cup of coffee, would have loved some black tea, took a long shower, talked with the people around the house for a few , and now I'm all cooled down, I'm ready to write this damn  review.

The wolf among us, is what I , as a fan of the fables comic and story-line by vertigo, found this game to be delightful, I'm not a big fan of tell tale games. But when I heard the big bad wolf would appear in a game, I bought this faster than the speed of light, and here are my toughs on it.

We are in New York, there ain't better place to find a story than new York, and what amazing story it is, we find yourself in the shows of Bigby wolf, the big bad wolf of the fables. In what we call a official territory called, fable-town, where the characters of fables, like snow white, toad and badger, a magic mirror who forces you to say rhymes if you wanna talk to him, etc. and our wolf friend, being one of the biggest, meanest and strongest creatures in the Fable world. He plays the role of sheriff. Weird place of putting a person like him, with the past he haves, taking care an looking for the safety of those he used to terrorize back in the good old days.

The story is good , and that I said up there is all I'm giving you. I will not rob anyone of the right to uncover this story by himself. And the game being only story, is like taking the foreshadowed betrayals from call of duty. Whats the joke. So, right ahead dim saying this, DON'T look it up, dont watch lets plays, don't freaking watch a friend play it, this is a game that will make you do decisions, and your decisions are important, at least some of them are.  The way you play, changes parts and bits of the story, things that seem like filler content, will come up as a major plot device in the later parts of it, nothing is trivial. And if you feel conflicted about a decision, believe me , its intentional.


Pros:
-game holds a long story, with chapter-like spread, that will keep you on the edge of your seat more often than most current games are capable of.

-Deep characters with human like emotions, and inhuman characteristics, this is a thing for those adult that loved fables as kids, and wish to have a more adult twist and insight in their stories.

-writing is very nice, simple, yet adult oriented, big words and deep talking don't make a adult story, the theme and the situations does, remember soul reaver? Think of that, with less theater.

-action shots all the time. Between the long periods of talking and interaction with what I think must be the cast that most personality haves in a telltale video game. You'll have to play the rougher part of the sheriff job. Quick time events everywhere, and for me, in a game of this kind, its okay to have a lot of those.

Cons:

-characters are different from the main comics. The act different but its not that much of a difference. Since time indeed makes people change, some of the characters tend to show hints to their development in the future.

-graphically speaking is an inferior game, at this day and hour I think most computers can run it from factory, but id does have its requirements, they comic style is seamless, yes, they ould have done better. With the kind of company they are working with. I mean we are talking DC comics here. Vertigo to be precise . V from vendetta, Sandman, that kind of quality demands more work than they put on the graphics aspect.

-the illusion of choice in many of the situations they could have added more approaches. It tends to end in: A) you do what you must to progress the story. And the game snaps at you for it. Or B) either choice would end down the same path.


All in all. Would I give this game a 100? no. but its very damn close. Id say 80/100 ,

reviewText:
The Wolf Among Us:
Well what can i really say except blown away. Even as I had solved the mystery, and that believe held right up until the end I suddenly got hit with a line by a character right at the end which completely turned everything around. The Mystery had been solved, but now it had grown even larger with but one line.
And the court room scene which seemed to go on and on with every moment feeling I had the upper hand then nothing at all just kept my eyes on the screen unblinking, watching as all the decisions and incident I had been part of coming to my aid or against me.
And in the end I feel that I made the right choices and will always make them, though unlike the Walking Dead I'm curious to see what would have occurred had I made different choices.

With great intrigue, quirky and original characters that had evolved from fairy tales (yeah I know that might sound like a contradiction) and a dose of film noir style action The Wolf Among Us is the best Telltale game yet to be made.

In a world where fairytale characters escaped in an Exodus to our world (the mundane as they refer to it) its never a happy ending and its a real treat watching all our favorite story time characters having to be hit with real world issues and how they have tried to adept. It gritty yet pleasant, emotional but exciting.

From start to end and even after from that final line I have mentioned a couple of times already that made me want to follow on makes me glad I brought this when the steam sale arrived and yet leaves me wishing I had purchased it from the start.

reviewText:
Finished the entire season and wow, what a good game. What ruined it for me is that at the very end it tells me that I should read the comic to find out what happened next. Why?

The walking dead tv show is immensely popular but is it's own entity and doesn't have to follow the comics much at all.
No disrespect to the comics but the artistic style of this game doesn't even resemble the source material.
Reading the comics after playing through this masterpiece is like buying a new bicicle and then deciding to use the stationary one at home. It just doesn't compute.
All I have to say is that there better be a season 2 or this game could be leaving fans at the altar. Comics look interesting, but aren't the same as a game where you get to choose what happens next and get to play so many different ways. Face it Telltale, this game deserves at least another season.

reviewText: Wolf Among Us is easily one of the single best video games I've ever had the chance to play, and has stuck with me after beating it like only a few games before it had *Games like Halo 1 when I was still feeling the pre-pubecent sting of young adult hood or Kotor with its many branching paths plus emphasis upon ones actions*.  A combination of maltese falcon meets the wire, Wolf Among Us firmly places the player into the shoes of gruff no nonsense sheriff Bigby Wolf as he has to navigate the seedy underworld of fabletown amidst the squalor of 1980's New York to either reaffirm himself as king supreme of bad dudes everywhere or as a miscast man trying to make up for the pain he's inflicted upon his fellow fables in years past. If you love crime drama's and have a taste for the strange, then I whole heartedly recommend this game. For that matter I can't help but recommend this game to everyone willing to divest their time in a good story driven by player choice and the consequences that follow! 10/10 Dogecoins

reviewText:
TellTale does it again!

I just finished the entire game, all five episodes although I haven't gone back just yet to see about other choices and how it can impact the game, but I can say right now that Wolf Among Us is just as engaging as the Walking Dead games, something that I am truly impressed with.

The gameplay is a point and click adventure, streamlined for casual players. Clickable items are shown with orbs, and most things to discover really aren't too far out of reach of newer players of the genre. The game also has a mode where you can turn that off if you want a challenge, but on your second playthrough you most likely remember where everything is, so if you want to go with this option, I'd do it on your first playthrough.

A lot of really cool characters, top notch voice acting, and some genuinely intense moments (although I've found that they are far more intense in the Walking Dead games by Tell Tale which I would also really recommend checking out). The graphics, while not going to be something that take advantage of your four SLI Titans, are bright, colorful and undeniably charming. They look like they popped out of a comic book.

I'd recommend it.
