reviewText:
This review is based on the first episode. If possible I'll try to update my review as the series continues. Also, I should note that I'm vaguely familiar with the comic Fables, but I've only read an issue or two of it and that was many years ago, so I approached this game more as a fan of The Walking Dead than a fan of the Fables franchise.

[EDIT: Second episode is out. I'll probably rewrite this review later because boy it's long, but I will say I enjoyed the second episode but not as much as the first--it feels shorter and the choices didn't have as much weight to them. I still like this game so far but it definitely feels like they had some problems trying to write the second episode.)

So, let's get straight to the point: Have you played The Walking Dead? Did you enjoy it? Then honestly I don't think I need to say anything more. Pick this game up. The same excellent writing, acting, and use of choice within the game is here, and in fact I feel like the illusion of choice and action sequences in this game are a big improvement over TWD. It's not just as good as TWD, in my opinion--it's BETTER. Whether or not the rest of the episodes will keep up with that is hard to say, but based on the first Episode alone this series has a much, much stronger opening than TWD. I'm hugely looking forward to the second episode, maybe even a little more than TWD Season 2 (and that's saying a LOT for me, since I consider the original TWD one of my favorite games of all time).

But what if you played the first Walking Dead and DIDN'T enjoy it? Well, then I can maybe still recommend this to you...depending on why you disliked it.

Did you dislike it because of the lack of gameplay? Then The Wolf Among Us probably won't change your mind. Although gameplay has been tweaked here and there, at it's core is still very similar to TWD in terms of its focus on interactive dialogue and choices than any other gameplay. There are action scenes here, and they're actually much more fun to play through than TWD--both because the controls, as I mentioned before, are a huge improvement over TWD overall, and also because it's just more fun to get into a fistfight with a fairytale character using some well though out quick time events than it is to try to deal with clunking shooting of (thankfully) slow-moving zombies--but in the first episode there's maybe three or so in two hours of gameplay, so that's still not really the focus.

However, if you disliked TWD because you're not as fond of the world of TWD, then I highly, highly recommend you give TWAU a try. This is certainly still obviously made by the same developer, but the world of Fables just feels much more different than TWD. It's still gritty and dark, and characters do die, but I do feel like with TWD franchise as a whole you can start to get a little tired of the constant death and overall gloomy tone focused on the depravity in human nature." Not that there isn't depravity to be found here--the first episode alone deals with themes like prostitution

reviewText: The Wolf Among Us launches with a promising opening, thanks to its stylish world, eccentric characters, curious plot, and tried and tested gameplay. Telltale could be on for another success if the quality of the work continues throughout the remaining four episodes. As a first episode, it succeeds at pulling players into a different thematic experience than The Walking Dead, and should make people excited for what is to come from the rest of the season.

reviewText: I love adventure games, and I love Western-style comic books and graphic novels. This is an adventure game based on a comic book series written by one of the principal writer's of Image Comics, 'The Walking Dead' series. The adaptation for television is now a blockbuster tv show. The gist of the 'Wolf Among Us', series is that Fables have been forced to update themselves in NYC, and you are the Big Bad Wolf, and Fabletown's Sheriff. There has been a murder in Fabletown, and as Sheriff you have to play the gumshoe and solve the case. Simple gameplay, with lots of story. Finally, your decisions, wise or otherwise, have a large effect on the results of the game. If you like the genre of this game, then its well worth the try.
